caption: Pont du Carrousel is an elegant bridge in Paris, connecting the Louvre Museum to the Left Bank of the Seine. Its understated yet graceful design blends seamlessly with the surrounding architecture, offering beautiful views of both the river and the iconic landmarks nearby. Walking across the bridge provides a peaceful and scenic route, especially during sunset when the city’s monuments are bathed in golden light. Whether you’re heading to the Louvre or simply enjoying a stroll along the Seine, Pont du Carrousel offers a serene and picturesque experience in the heart of Paris.

Despite the original bridge being completed in 1843, this construction dates from 1939. It was realigned to direct traffic and pedestrians to the Carrousel in the Louvre after which the bridge is now named. Uninspiring to the eye, it is the history that facinates. The four statues, two at either end, were designed by the same artist, Louis Petitot (1794 - 1862). They were originally installed on the bridge in 1847 and were replaced on their pedestals when the bridge was strengthened in 1908.

Beautiful views on both the sides. This is the entrance for the famous Louvre. You get nice pictures with those monuments in the background. Clicking the picture at the centre of the bridge is recommended.
A bridge for both pedestrians and cars. It is not one of the 37 most beautiful bridge in Paris but it serves its purpose. It heads into one of the side entrances to the Louvre.
Quite a wide stone bridge crossing the seine that feeds into the Louvre complex
One of the many bridges that crosses the River Seine, its architecture is simple and contains some ornamental elements.
One of the many walking bridges crossing over the river Seine, it’s not as striking as others, but functional.
It’s a beautiful bridge to watch cathedral and san river. Bridge itself is arched very beautiful.
Nice spot to take in a beautiful Paris night scene.

As I walked across the Pont du Carousel, I was struck by the breathtaking views of the Seine and the surrounding landmarks. This bridge is truly a marvel of engineering and design, and I couldn't help but feel awed by its beauty.  The Pont du Carousel is a must-see attraction for anyone visiting Paris. The bridge is well-maintained and offers a comfortable walking experience. The ambiance is serene, and the sound of the river flowing beneath the bridge is simply mesmerizing.  One of the things that sets the Pont du Carousel apart from other bridges in Paris is the unique views it offers. From here, you can see the Louvre Museum, the Eiffel Tower, and Notre-Dame Cathedral all in one glance. It's truly a photographer's dream come true.  I have no complaints or criticisms to make about this place. I found it to be an incredibly enjoyable and peaceful experience.  As for improving the place, I can suggest to add some benches along the bridge for visitors to sit and enjoy the view for a longer period.  I give the Pont du Carousel Paris a five-star rating. It's a special place that captures the essence of Paris and provides a memorable experience for visitors. I would highly recommend this attraction to anyone visiting Paris.
Cool bridge...as far as bridges go. Nothing unique, but quite majestic.
This is exact bridge Spencer Diana posed in 1977 trip to Paris. And the tunnel she passed away was just 4Km away from this place. Damn RIP Diana
Its a good and beautiful place
Magnificent view of this bridge connecting the two banks of the Seine. Walking there, especially at sunset, is always a pleasure.
Today's, no longer very special, bridge from 1939 replaces a wonderful iron bridge from 1843. The name goes back to an equestrian festival on the initiative of Louis XIV in 1662.

The Carousel Bridge on the Seine... it's an excellent place that connects the Louvre Carrousel and Saint Germain, not too busy, no traffic jams. An excellent view of the Seine. There is a pedestrian crossing. There is a bicycle area.
The bridge is usually busy. But from here you have a nice view of the banks of the Seine. Recommended in the evening for a short detour or if you're passing by anyway.
Very beautiful view from this bridge, going to the Louvre carousel or leaving the Louvre to go to Saint Germain. Less busy than the rest of the Parisian bridges. 5/5
A large bridge leads to the Louvre

In the movie The Da Vinci Code, the truck that threw the GPS sticked to soap from the Louvre toilet crossed here. The scene in which the detectives played by Jean Reno chase after him, mistaking him for jumping and running away.
Practical bridge to connect either to the Louvre on the right or to the left to enjoy the Tuileries garden.
A beautiful wide bridge through which we can cross from the Louvre towards, for example, the Museum d'Orsay.
It looks very majestic, especially in the evening - a must on a city trip
Cold last night after 10 km of demonstration against the ignominies of Macron, but Paris bright :-)
Bridge over the river
Superb spot for the plane parade on July 14
Beautiful for photos
Gorgeous
One of the most beautiful bridges in Paris
